posts.title: Pijonieriai , Pijonieriai
posts.description:
2 July 1985 - Columbia Records released Freddie Mercuryâ€™s â€œLiving On My Ownâ€ as a single, with â€œShe Blows Hot And Coldâ€ on the B-side in the USA ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ 
â€œIf you listen to my song â€˜Living On My Ownâ€™, that is very me. Itâ€™s living on my own, but having fun. Thereâ€™s a bit in the middle where I do my scat singing and Iâ€™m just saying that when you think about somebody like me, my lifestyle, I have to go around the world and live in hotels and that can be a very lonely life. But I chose it. That song is not dealing with people who are living on their own in basement flats, or situations like that, itâ€™s my living on my own. I mean, you can have a whole shoal of people looking after you, but in the end they all go away and you are in a hotel room on your own. Iâ€™m not complaining though. Itâ€™s a different kind of living on my own. People with my success can be lonely and can live on their own as well. Iâ€™m just saying that Iâ€™m living on my own and Iâ€™m having a boogie time! Does that make sense, honey?â€ ğŸ’›
(Freddie Mercury) 
â€œMercuryâ€™s solo song â€˜Living On My Ownâ€™, originally released in 1985, but which reached number one in the UK two years after his death after getting a club-friendly remix, is a catchy expression of loneliness that paints Mercury as a bachelor, but not necessarily a â€˜confirmed bachelorâ€™ in the now somewhat dated euphemistic sense. He was so outrageously camp, it was almost like a double bluff.  Everything was about subtext with Freddie Mercury.â€ 
(Martin Aston, author of Breaking Down The Walls Of Heartache: How Music Came Out)
